awd_titl_txt: ChemAttitudes: Using Design-Based Research to Develop and Disseminate Strategies and Materials to Support Chemistry Interest, Relevance, and Self-Efficacy
awd_abstract_narration:
Chemistry is an important and widely relevant field of science.  However, when compared with other STEM content areas, chemistry is under-represented in U.S. science museums and other informal educational environments.  This project will build, and build knowledge about, innovative approaches to delivering informal science learning activities in chemistry. The project will not only increase public interest and understanding of chemistry but also increase public perception of chemistry's relevance and increase the public's self-efficacy with respect to chemistry. This project outcomes will include a guide for practitioners along with activity materials that will be packaged into a kit, distributed, and replicated for use by informal science educators, chemists, and chemistry students at 250 sites across the U.S. The project team will reach out to organizations that serve diverse audiences and diverse geographic locations, including organizations in rural and inner-city areas. The kits will provide guidance on engaging girls, people with various abilities, Spanish speakers, and other diverse audiences, and include materials in Spanish. Written guides, training videos, and training slides will be included to support training in science communication in general, as well as chemistry in particular.  This project is supported by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds research and innovative resources for use in a variety of settings, as a part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments.

This project will take an innovative approach to develop informal educational activities and materials about chemistry. Rather than starting with content goals, the project will start with a theoretical framework drawn from research about affecting attitudes about science related to interest, relevance, and self-efficacy. A design-based research approach (DBR) will be used to apply that framework to the development of hands-on educational activities about chemistry, while also testing and modifying the framework itself. (DBR blends empirical educational research with the theory-driven design of learning environments.) Existing or new educational activities that appear to embody key characteristics defined in the framework will be tested with public audiences for their impact on visitors. Researchers and educators will determine how different characteristics of the educational activities defined in the framework affect the outcomes. The activities will be modified and tested iteratively until the investigators achieve close alignment between framework and impacts.. The project team will continue the design-based research approach both to examine groups of activities in which synergies can have impacts beyond single interactions as well as to examine varied ways of training facilitators who can also significantly affect outcomes. In this way, the project will generate knowledge about how kits of hands-on informal learning activities can stimulate attitudes of interest, relevance, and self-efficacy with respect to the neglected field of chemistry. The project teams will broadly disseminate project outcomes within the educational research, science and informal Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) education communities. While this project will focus on chemistry, the strategies it will develop and test through a design-based research process will provide valuable insight into effective approaches for informal STEM education more broadly.

por.por_cntn:
Chemistry is everywhere in the world around us and in ourselves. It's in the air we breathe, the water we drink, the food we eat, the soil we grow that food in, the medicines we take, the clothes we wear, the fuels we use to get around, and all of the materials both natural and human-made that surround us. Chemistry has been, however, the least represented of the major science fields in science museums and other informal science educational media. In 2016, the National Academies of Science, Engineering, and Medicine called upon researchers and educators who work in informal environments like science museums to collaborate in conducting research about chemistry learning and to advance successful practices in communication and informal education about chemistry.

A study published by the Royal Society of Chemistry in the United Kingdom in 2015 found that the most significant challenge for public engagement in learning about chemistry is that public audiences had little interest in chemistry and viewed it as abstract, distant from the individual, not applied to the real world, and inaccessible. This view of chemistry was true even among audiences that considered science to be fun, welcoming, and accessible to everyone. Seemingly schools, science museums, educational television and other media had created positive attitudes toward learning science that did not apply to chemistry.

The Museum of Science, Boston brought together researchers, educators, and chemists from the Museum of Science, the Science Museum of Minnesota, Sciencenter (Ithaca), the National Informal STEM Education Network, University of Wisconsin-Madison, and the American Chemical Society to address these challenges in a project called "ChemAttitudes." The project used a process called "design-based research" to develop and test a theoretical framework that would identify specific educational strategies for promoting interest, a sense of relevance, and feelings of self-efficacy in public audiences with respect to chemistry, while at the same time developing  hands-on educational activities that embody those strategies. University researchers with expertise in science communication, museum researchers with expertise in informal education, museum educators, scientists with expertise in chemistry, and public audiences were involved throughout the process.

Eleven of the hands-on activities developed were packaged into Explore Science: Let's Do Chemistry kits that included materials to facilitate use of the activities, including:  safety, professional development, and training materials; event planning and promotional materials; training videos; and National Chemistry Week materials. A total of 250 copies of the physical kit were distributed for free through a competitive application process in 2018 to science and children's museums, other informal science education organizations, and university- and high school-based groups participating in the American Chemical Society's National Chemistry Week in October 2018. Kits were awarded to sites in all 50 states, DC, and Puerto Rico. In addition, a digital version of the kit is freely available here: https://www.nisenet.org/chemistry-kit-contents.

Beyond these educational materials, the project also developed a tested theoretical framework for stimulating interest, sense of relevance, and feelings of self-efficacy with respect to chemistry through hands-on activities. The framework includes educational design strategies that look both at activity content (such as chemistry concepts, applications, and connections to everyday life) and activity format (such as allowing for observation of phenomena, allowing for use of tools and materials, or evoking familiar experiences). Research outcomes also include a facilitation framework built around three aspects of facilitation: inviting participation, supporting exploration, and deepening understanding. Aspects of the framework, specifically the strategies related to content, were additionally tested in broader surveys of U.S. adults that did not include hands-on activities. Findings were summarized in a Research Reference Guide, put into context in a Research to Practice Guide, and reported on in professional conference presentations and peer-reviewed publications.

In the final years of the project, the team developed a train-the-trainer workshop to introduce the frameworks and associated strategies to chemistry and informal science education professionals who are in a position to train others who engage public audiences in learning about chemistry. Originally planned as in-person workshops at professional conferences, the team pivoted to online workshops in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Overall, a diverse group of 73 professionals participated in multi-session online workshops and planned to use what they learned in future professional development and training activities. American Chemical Society staff have embedded ChemAttitudes framework strategies into their ongoing work, and educators in science museums around the country continue to use their Let's to Chemistry kits to engage public audiences. The workshop materials are freely available here: https://www.nisenet.org/lets-do-chemistry-train-trainer-workshops. 

Through this project, the ChemAttitudes team has been able to increase the amount and quality of chemistry education at sites of public outreach and informal science education throughout the country and to create new knowledge in the form of a tested framework and training materials that will result in ongoing impacts beyond the life of the project.
